url_structure.voice_variations_detected: Consumer marketing uses aspirational, creativity-first language. Enterprise uses ROI, scale, trust, and integration language. Docs/support are procedural and directive. Corporate pages are mission-led and formal.

discovery.coverage_assessment: Sampled core B2C product marketing and pricing pages under /creativecloud and /acrobat (DE and EN variants), B2B product and pricing pages on business.adobe.com, developer portal API and console docs, Experience League enterprise documentation, Help Center and PSIRT, legal terms and enterprise licensing, careers, investor relations, corporate responsibility and diversity, and official blog articles spanning creativity and security. Evidence includes recent B2B positioning, developer API references, help workflows, and legal/compliance statements.

voice_clusters.description: Consumer-focused creative and document marketing voice centered on empowerment, ease, and inspiration.
B2B/enterprise solutions voice focused on outcomes, scalability, security, and integration with decision-maker framing.
Technical reference and tutorial voice with precise, task-oriented guidance and API-specific terminology.
Service, compliance, and corporate voice with formal tone, obligations, and process clarity.

clustering.sub_brand_rationale: Created sub-brands for Enterprise and Developers/Docs due to deliberate audience segmentation, consistent vocabulary, and scope. Support/Legal/Corporate grouped for completeness but not treated as market-facing sub-brands.

competitive_context.industry: Creative software and digital experience platforms
competitive_context.industry_characteristics: Two-track market voice: B2C creativity and productivity language for individuals; B2B CXM language emphasizing scale, data, personalization, security, and ROI. Developer materials are terse, versioned, and example-led.

similar_brands.name: Salesforce (Marketing Cloud)
similar_brands.similarity: Outcome-led enterprise messaging around personalization at scale, integrations, and trust/compliance.

similar_brands.name: Microsoft (Surface/365 + Power Platform)
similar_brands.similarity: Productivity framing for individuals and enterprises; trust and security emphasis.

similar_brands.name: Canva
similar_brands.similarity: Accessible creativity and speed-to-output for non-experts; inspirational B2C tone.

contrasting_brands.name: Mailchimp
contrasting_brands.contrast: Conversational, playful SMB tone; fewer enterprise-scale claims.

contrasting_brands.name: Serif Affinity
contrasting_brands.contrast: One-time-purchase, craft-first product voice; minimal enterprise narrative.

contrasting_brands.name: Oracle CX
contrasting_brands.contrast: Highly technical and procurement-heavy tone; less creative positioning.

competitive_context.positioning: Bridges creative tools, document workflows, and enterprise CXM under one umbrella. Leads with creativity for individuals and with ROI and scale for enterprises.
competitive_context.differentiation: Unique span from creator apps to enterprise CXM and data platform; strong trust/compliance narrative; recurring ‘Creativity for All’ mission anchoring both segments.
competitive_context.evolution: Voice has shifted from desktop app-centric to cloud, AI-first, and cross-cloud integration. Enterprise language increasingly highlights real-time profiles, personalization, and governance.

main_profile.communication_style: Lead with outcomes and inspiration, then enumerate concrete tools and steps. Frequent CTA pairs like “Free trial” and “Buy now.” Uses crisp headers and scannable lists. Highlights AI as a speed and quality multiplier while keeping user control in focus.
main_profile.target_audience: Individual creators, students, freelancers, small teams evaluating creative or PDF tools.

formality_level.label: professional-casual
formality_level.description: Friendly retail tone with precise product nouns. Short sentences and direct CTAs. Minimal jargon compared to enterprise.

vocabulary.label: accessible-technical
vocabulary.word_complexity: Simple verbs and concrete feature names. Technical nouns appear but are explained or linked.
signature_phrases: Changing the world through digital experiences
vocabulary.industry_terms_usage: Mentions of generative AI, templates, assets, credits, and cloud documents appear with plain-language gloss.

emotional_tone.label: warm-enthusiastic
emotional_tone.description: Positive, future-facing, and inclusive. Frames creativity as accessible and impactful.

brand_personality.description: Values imagination supported by advanced tools. Blends artistry and engineering.

core_values.name: Creativity access
core_values.evidence: Mission and programs labeled “Creativity for All.” ([Adobe][1])

core_values.name: Trust & security
core_values.evidence: Trust Center, PSIRT, and compliance content across legal and security blogs. ([Adobe][2])

core_values.name: Innovation at scale
core_values.evidence: Cross-cloud AI features and claims about real-time personalization and platform unification. ([Adobe for Business][3])

dos: Lead with user benefits before features.
Explain technical terms briefly and link to details.
Highlight AI as an accelerator, not a replacement.
Use inclusive, global language and examples.
donts: Do not open with procurement or compliance detail.
Do not use insider acronyms without expansion.
Do not overpromise outcomes without tool context.
Do not minimize learning curves; provide tutorials.
Do not mix developer error codes into marketing copy.

good_examples.text: Changing the world through personalized digital experiences.
Generate images, video, and audio with leading AI models.
good_examples.why_good: Benefit-first and concrete about AI capability. ([Adobe][5])

good_examples.text: Get started with over 20 apps, templates, and tutorials.
good_examples.why_good: Direct CTA with clear value stack. ([Adobe][6])

bad_examples.text: Our SKU tiering utilizes heterogenous microservices to operationalize ideation.
Buy now or miss out forever on creativity.
We guarantee professional results instantly with zero effort.
bad_examples.why_bad: Overpromise; ignores learning and user agency.

sub_brands.name: Adobe for Business / Experience Cloud
sub_brands.context: Enterprise marketing and solution pages addressing CMOs, CIOs, product and data leaders. Focus on Experience Cloud, Experience Platform, Acrobat for business, and integrations.
sub_brands.distinction_rationale: Deliberate B2B voice shift: ROI, scale, compliance, integration, and decision-maker language across product, pricing, and event pages.

profile.communication_style: Start with business challenges and KPIs, then map to capabilities and proofs. Cite scale, real-time data, and interoperability. Include compliance and governance notes. Use customer logos and event content as social proof.
profile.target_audience: Enterprise decision-makers and practitioners in marketing, data, product, IT, and operations.

formality_level.label: formal-professional
formality_level.description: Dense nouns, platform terms, and explicit ROI framing. Minimal idiom. Numbers and qualifiers appear frequently.

vocabulary.label: business-technical
vocabulary.industry_terms_usage: Uses CDP, identity graph, activation, governance, and zero/first-party data with assumed literacy.

emotional_tone.label: confident-pragmatic
emotional_tone.description: Controlled enthusiasm. Emphasis on certainty, risk reduction, and operational efficiency.

brand_personality.description: Designs reliable systems that scale across teams and geographies.

core_values.name: Business impact
core_values.evidence: Pricing, product pages, and Summit content highlight measurable outcomes and scale. ([Adobe for Business][7])

core_values.name: Security & compliance
core_values.evidence: Trust Center and regulatory pages linked from enterprise terms. ([Adobe][2])

core_values.name: Interoperability
core_values.evidence: Experience Platform positioned as shared, composable foundation. ([Adobe for Business][3])

dos: Name integrations and data flows plainly.
Highlight customer proof and analyst validation.
Tie features to roles and workflows.
donts: Do not use casual consumer language.
Do not bury implementation detail when it affects risk.
Do not lead with UI flourish over outcomes.
Do not omit regional compliance mentions when relevant.
Do not assume marketing-only readers; include IT implications.

good_examples.text: Deliver personalized experiences at scale with real-time profiles ready for activation.
good_examples.why_good: Concise promise with scale and capability. ([Adobe for Business][7])

good_examples.text: A secure, single system of truth powers data-driven decisions and real-time orchestration.
good_examples.why_good: Platform language plus outcomes. ([Adobe for Business][3])

good_examples.text: Adobe Acrobat Sign transforms e-signatures with an accessibility-first recipient experience.
good_examples.why_good: Outcome plus differentiator and accessibility. ([Experience League][8])

bad_examples.text: Make cool stuff with vibes — for enterprises!
Our CDP is neat and kind of speedy sometimes.

bad_examples.why_bad: Avoids compliance and proof, unacceptable for B2B buyers.

sub_brands.name: Adobe Developers & Experience League
sub_brands.context: Developer portal APIs, SDKs, and enterprise documentation for implementers, admins, and technical practitioners.
sub_brands.distinction_rationale: Highly structured, imperative, example-led language with precise nouns and versioning. Separate from marketing voice.

profile.communication_style: Overview → prerequisites → step-by-step → examples → references. Links to related SDKs and Postman collections. Consistent anchor navigation and tables.
profile.target_audience: Developers, solution architects, admins, data engineers, and technical marketers implementing Adobe services.

formality_level.label: formal-technical
formality_level.description: Precise modals, consistent nomenclature, and explicit constraints.

vocabulary.label: technical
vocabulary.word_complexity: Uses API, endpoint, auth, scopes, CRUD, webhook, payload, rate limit, and Postman.
signature_phrases: Use the API to perform CRUD operations
Receive job completion notifications via webhook
vocabulary.industry_terms_usage: API and platform terms used exactly as defined; links to schema and OpenAPI specs.

emotional_tone.label: neutral-informational
emotional_tone.description: Minimal affect. Focus on correctness and completeness.

core_values.name: Clarity
core_values.evidence: High-level overviews with links to detailed references. ([Adobe Developer][9])

core_values.name: Completeness
core_values.evidence: OpenAPI specs, SDKs, and Postman collections. ([Adobe Developer][10])

core_values.name: Productivity
core_values.evidence: Aggregated API catalog and filterable listings. ([Adobe Developer][11])

dos: Use consistent terminology with linked definitions.
Provide working examples and sample payloads.
State prerequisites and auth flows up front.
Cross-link to tutorials and release notes.
donts: Do not embed sales content in procedural steps.
Do not use ambiguous verbs like ‘handle’ without specifics.
Do not omit pagination and rate-limit behavior.
Do not assume prior product context; link it.

good_examples.text: Using Platform APIs, you can programmatically perform CRUD operations against data.
good_examples.why_good: Clear capability statement using standard terms. ([Adobe Developer][9])

good_examples.text: Start building today. Explore the APIs offered by products and view documentation.
good_examples.why_good: Direct imperative and navigation clarity. ([Adobe Developer][11])

good_examples.text: Receive job completion notifications through Webhook instead of polling.
good_examples.why_good: Offers a best-practice alternative with exact term. ([Adobe Developer][12])

bad_examples.text: Our APIs are magical and will just work.

diversity_assessment: Mix of B2C creative and document pages, multi-region variants (DE, JP), enterprise solution and pricing, developer APIs and Experience League docs, help and PSIRT, legal terms, corporate responsibility and diversity, careers and investor relations. Sources spanned product, platform, security, and corporate communications.
